text: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs. The air sacs may fill with fluid or pus, causing cough with phlegm or pus, fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. Bacteria, viruses, and fungi can cause pneumonia. Symptoms include chest pain when breathing or coughing, confusion or changes in mental awareness, cough with phlegm, fatigue, fever, sweating and shaking chills, lower than normal body temperature, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. Treatment depends on the type and severity of pneumonia and may include antibiotics, antiviral medications, or antifungal medications.

Diabetes is a chronic health condition that affects how your body turns food into energy. There are three main types: type 1, type 2, and gestational diabetes. Type 1 diabetes occurs when the immune system attacks and destroys the insulin-producing cells in the pancreas. Type 2 diabetes occurs when the body becomes resistant to insulin or doesn't make enough insulin. Symptoms include increased thirst, frequent urination, extreme fatigue, blurred vision, and slow-healing sores. Management includes blood sugar monitoring, healthy eating, regular physical activity, and medication or insulin therapy.

Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a common condition where the force of blood against artery walls is consistently too high. It often has no symptoms but can lead to serious health problems like heart disease and stroke. Risk factors include age, family history, being overweight, lack of physical activity, tobacco use, too much sodium in diet, and stress. Treatment includes lifestyle changes like eating a healthy diet, exercising regularly, maintaining a healthy weight, and medications such as ACE inhibitors, diuretics, and calcium channel blockers.

Chest pain can have many causes, ranging from minor to life-threatening. Common causes include heartburn, muscle strain, anxiety, and respiratory infections. Serious causes include heart attack, angina, pulmonary embolism, and aortic dissection. Symptoms vary depending on the cause but may include sharp or dull pain, pressure or tightness, burning sensation, or pain that radiates to other areas. Immediate medical attention is required for severe chest pain, especially if accompanied by shortness of breath, nausea, or pain radiating to the arm or jaw.

Chronic pain is pain that lasts longer than 12 weeks despite medication or treatment. It can result from an injury, illness, or have no apparent cause. Common types include back pain, arthritis pain, neuropathic pain, and headaches. Management strategies include physical therapy, psychological counseling, medications like NSAIDs, opioids, or antidepressants, alternative therapies like acupuncture or massage, and lifestyle modifications. The goal is to improve function and quality of life while reducing pain intensity.

Stroke occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. There are two main types: ischemic stroke (caused by blocked arteries) and hemorrhagic stroke (caused by bleeding in the brain). Symptoms include sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg, confusion, trouble speaking, vision problems, dizziness, and severe headache. Treatment depends on the type of stroke and may include clot-busting drugs, surgery, or rehabilitation therapy.

Depression is a mood disorder that causes persistent feelings of sadness and loss of interest. It affects how you feel, think, and behave and can lead to emotional and physical problems. Symptoms include feelings of sadness, emptiness, or hopelessness, loss of interest in activities, fatigue, sleep disturbances, appetite changes, anxiety, and thoughts of death or suicide. Treatment options include psychotherapy, medications like antidepressants, and lifestyle changes. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial for recovery.

Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition that causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, making breathing difficult. Common triggers include allergens, respiratory infections, exercise, cold air, and stress. Symptoms include wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing. Treatment involves long-term control medications like inhaled corticosteroids and quick-relief medications like bronchodilators. Management also includes identifying and avoiding triggers and monitoring lung function.

Osteoarthritis is the most common form of arthritis, affecting millions of people worldwide. It occurs when the protective cartilage that cushions the ends of bones wears down over time. It can affect any joint but commonly affects hands, knees, hips, and spine. Symptoms include joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and reduced range of motion. Risk factors include age, obesity, joint injuries, and genetics. Treatment includes pain medications, physical therapy, joint injections, and in severe cases, joint replacement surgery.

Migraine is a neurological condition characterized by recurrent, severe headaches that typically affect one side of the head. Symptoms include throbbing pain, sensitivity to light and sound, nausea, and vomiting. Migraine attacks can last from hours to days and may be preceded by warning signs called auras. Triggers include stress, hormonal changes, certain foods, sleep disturbances, and environmental factors. Treatment includes acute medications for pain relief and preventive medications to reduce frequency and severity of attacks.
